question_text: A 59-year-old man is evaluated for fever, a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 7 weeks; fatigue; malaise; and productive cough, occasionally with blood.Chest radiograph is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is tuberculosis (Option D). The frontal chest radiograph demonstrates bilateral upper lobe infiltrates with cavitation. A left pleural effusion is also present. Reactivation (postprimary) pulmonary tuberculosis may be associated with thin-walled cavities or cavities found within an area of patchy airspace opacity. Most tuberculous pulmonary cavities do not contain fluid, but up to 20% may demonstrate an air-fluid interface because of bacterial superinfection or bleeding.
